{{short description|Favoritism granted to relatives or friends}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2020}} {{Political corruption sidebar}} {{Discrimination sidebar|state=collapsed}} '''Nepotism''' is [[In-group favoritism|favoritism]] that is granted to [[Kinship|relatives]] or [[friend]]s in various fields, including business, politics, entertainment, sports, religion and other activities. The term originated with the assignment of nephews to important positions by [[Catholicism|Catholic]] [[pope]]s and [[bishop]]s.
Nepotism has been criticized since the ancient times by several philosophers, including [[Aristotle]], [[Valluvar]], and [[Confucius]]. For instance, the ancient Indian philosopher Valluvar condemned nepotism as both evil and unwise.<ref name="PSSundaram_Kural">{{cite book | last = Sundaram | first = P. S. | author-link = | title = Tiruvalluvar: The Kural | publisher = Penguin Books | series = | volume = | edition = First | date = 1990 | location = Gurgaon | pages = 12 | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-14-400009-8 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
== Origins == {{Main|Cardinal-nephew}} The term comes from Italian word ''nepotismo'',<ref name="dictionary">[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism "Nepotism."] Dictionary.com. Retrieved 20 June 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=In Praise of Nepotism: A Natural History |work=[[Adam Bellow]] Booknotes interview transcript |url=http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926013727/http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archivedate=26 September 2010 |accessdate=10 September 2013}} </ref> which is based on Latin root ''nepos'' meaning nephew.<ref>{{cite web |title=Article nepos |work=CTCWeb Glossary |url=http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |accessdate=10 September 2013}} </ref> Since the [[Middle Ages]] and until the late 17th century, some [[Catholicism|Catholic]] [[pope]]s and [[bishop]]s – who had taken vows of [[chastity]] and, therefore, usually had no legitimate offspring of their own – gave their nephews such positions of preference as were often accorded by fathers to sons.<ref name="Article Nepotism">{{cite web|title=Article Nepotism |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://catholic-forum.com/saints/ncd05726.htm |accessdate=12 July 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archivedate=24 February 2007 }} </ref>
Several popes [[Cardinal-nephew|elevated nephews]] and other relatives to the [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinalate]]. Often, such appointments were a means of continuing a papal "dynasty".<ref>{{cite book|author1=Gianvittorio Signorotto|author2=Maria Antonietta Visceglia|title=Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2W1tc-wf5DQC&pg=PA114|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=21 March 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43141-5|pages=114–116}}</ref> For instance, [[Pope Callixtus III]], head of the [[House of Borgia|Borgia]] family, made two of his nephews cardinals; one of them, Rodrigo, later used his position as a cardinal as a stepping stone to the papacy, becoming [[Pope Alexander VI]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Article Pope Alexander VI |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |accessdate=12 July 2007 }} </ref> Alexander then elevated Alessandro Farnese, his mistress's brother, to cardinal; Farnese would later go on to become [[Pope Paul III]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Article Pope Paul III |encyclopedia=Catholic Encyclopedia |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |accessdate=12 July 2007 }} </ref>
Paul III also engaged in nepotism, appointing, for instance, two nephews, aged 14 and 16, as cardinals. The practice was finally limited when [[Pope Innocent XII]] issued the [[Papal bull|bull]] ''[[Romanum decet Pontificem]]'', in 1692.<ref name="Article Nepotism"/> The papal bull prohibited popes in all times from bestowing estates, offices, or revenues on any relative, with the exception that one qualified relative (at most) could be made a cardinal.<ref>{{cite book|author=Anura Gurugé|title=The Next Pope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5JVthemvvwC&pg=PA115|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=16 February 2010|publisher=Anura Guruge|isbn=978-0-615-35372-2|page=115}}</ref>
===Mention in ancient literature=== In the [[Book of Porul|second book]] of the [[Tirukkural|Kural literature]], which forms a manual for governments and corporations, [[Valluvar]] suggests about nepotism and favouritism thus: "If you choose an unfit person for your job just because you love and you like him, he will lead you to endless follies."<ref>[https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/rediscovering-a-management-and-leadership-manual-in-ancient-indian-literature/ Rediscovering a Management and Leadership Manual in Ancient Indian Literature - Knowledge@Wharton<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> According to him, nepotism is both evil and unwise.<ref name="PSSundaram_Kural"/>
== Types ==
=== Political === Nepotism is a common accusation in politics when the relative of a powerful figure ascends to similar power seemingly without appropriate qualifications. The [[British English]] expression "[[Bob's your uncle]]" is thought to have originated when [[Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury]], promoted his nephew, [[Arthur Balfour]], to the esteemed post of [[Chief Secretary for Ireland]], which was widely seen as an act of nepotism.<ref name=Trahair>[https://books.google.com/books?id=K0zrsHO27-wC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72 ''From Aristotelian to Reaganomics: A Dictionary of Eponyms With Biographies in the Social Science''], by R. C. S. Trahair, [[Greenwood Publishing Group]], 1994, p. 72. Retrieved online from [[Google Books]], 30 July 2012.</ref>
=== Organizational === Nepotism can also occur within organizations, when a person is employed due to their familial ties. It is generally seen as unethical, both on the part of the employer and employee.<ref>"Richard Utz, "Beyond Consanguinity," ''[https://www.insidehighered.com/advice/2010/03/24/beyond-consanguinity Inside Higher Ed]'', 24 March, 2010.</ref>
==== In employment ==== Nepotism at work can mean increased opportunity at a job, attaining the job or being paid more than other similarly situated people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/nepotismatwork.html |title=Nepotism at Work |publisher=Safeworkers.co.uk |date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Arguments are made both for and against employment granted due to a family connection, which is most common in small, family run businesses. On one hand, nepotism can provide stability and continuity. Critics cite studies that demonstrate decreased morale and commitment from non-related employees,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |title=Family Ties: Handling Nepotism Within Your Business - Perspectives - Inside INdiana Business with Gerry Dick |publisher=Insideindianabusiness.com |date=9 November 2010 |accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> and a generally negative attitude towards superior positions filled through nepotism. An article from ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine stated "there is no ladder to climb when the top rung is reserved for people with a certain name."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |title=Is Nepotism So Bad? |work=Forbes |date= |accessdate=20 June 2013 |first=Klaus |last=Kneale}}</ref> Some businesses forbid nepotism as an ethical matter, considering it too troublesome and disruptive.{{cn|date=November 2020}}
====In entertainment==== Outside of national politics, accusations of "nepotism" are made in instances of ''[[prima facie]]'' favoritism to relatives, in such cases as: * [[Peaches Geldof]]'s role as magazine editor in an [[MTV]] reality show – produced by a company owned by her father [[Bob Geldof]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/showbiz/showbiznews/2008/03/16/peaches-geldof-bags-tv-reality-show-as-magazine-editor-98487-20353319/ |title=Peaches Geldof bags TV reality show as magazine editor |publisher=Sundaymirror.co.uk |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524020700/http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/showbiz/showbiznews/2008/03/16/peaches-geldof-bags-tv-reality-show-as-magazine-editor-98487-20353319/ |archivedate=24 May 2008 }}</ref> * [[Tori Spelling]]'s breakout role on [[Beverly Hills 90210]] as a result of her father [[Aaron Spelling]]'s involvement with the show.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} * Hollywood's [[Coppola family tree|Coppola family]] includes many distinguished filmmakers and actors. The careers of [[Sofia Coppola]], [[Nicolas Cage]], and [[Jason Schwartzman]] have been attributed to aid by director [[Francis Ford Coppola]], who cast his daughter Sofia in ''[[The Godfather Part III]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/EXTRA_Nepotism_in_the_Directors_Chair/312221 |title=EXTRA: Nepotism in the Director's Chair at |publisher=Hollywood.com |date=21 April 2000 |accessdate=6 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006085336/http://www.hollywood.com/news/EXTRA_Nepotism_in_the_Directors_Chair/312221|archivedate=6 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://spiritof1976.livejournal.com/338603.html |title=Nothing is true, everything is permitted - Coppola nepotism hate |publisher=Spiritof1976.livejournal.com |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> Cage changed his last name in order to distance himself from such charges.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000115/bio Nicolas Cage - imdb biography<!--Bot-generated title-->]</ref>
== Selected examples by country ==
=== Australia === [[Anna Bligh]], who won the 2009 Queensland State election, has been accused of nepotism by giving her husband Greg Withers a position as the Office of Climate Change head.<ref name="houghton">Houghton, Des (28 June 2008). [http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,23931778-5012449,00.html "Anna Bligh's Labor in trouble in the polls"] ''Couriermail'', 28 June 2008. Retrieved 2009-08-17.</ref>
Shortly after his appointment as the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney in 2001, [[Peter Jensen (bishop)|Peter Jensen]] was accused, in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation interview, of nepotism after nominating his brother [[Phillip Jensen]] as Dean of Sydney and appointing his wife Christine Jensen to an official position in the Sydney diocese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s728866.htm |title=AM - Archbishop Jensen accused of nepotism |work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=18 November 2002 |accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
===Greece=== In Greece it is common practice for family members of current or former party leaders to be party members and get appointed as ministers when the party is in government.<ref>https://www.lifo.gr/now/politics/255152/to-fainomeno-tis-oikogeneiokratias-sti-voyli-apo-ti-metapoliteysi-mexri-simera</ref> In addition, there have been 3 Prime ministers from the [[List of political families in Greece#P|Papandreou family]]<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/13/business/global/papandreou-family-shapes-history-in-greece.html</ref>, 2 from the [[List of political families in Greece#M|Mitsotakis family ]](1 currently serving)<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-48902766</ref>, 2 from the [[List of political families in Greece#K|Karamanlis family ]](a 3rd one is currently serving as Minister of transportation).
=== Azerbaijan === On 21 February 2017, [[President of Azerbaijan]] [[Ilham Aliyev]] appointed his wife [[Mehriban Aliyeva]] to be [[Vice President of Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meeting of Security Council held under chairmanship of President Ilham Aliyev VIDEO|url=http://azertag.az/en/xeber/1037089|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Azertag|date=21 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>
=== Belgium === Over the past decade, criticism has been growing over the creation of political dynasties in Belgium, in which all of the traditional political parties have been involved. This phenomenon has been explained by the fact that prominent party members control the ranking of candidates on party lists for elections and a candidate's place on a list determines whether or not he or she is elected. Another justification for the phenomenon is the importance of name recognition for collecting votes.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/3376470/__Politiek_Belgie_is_familiezaak__.html?p=7,1 |title=Politiek België is familiezaak - Buitenland - Telegraaf.nl [24 uur actueel, ook mobiel] [buitenland] |publisher=Telegraaf.nl |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
Claims of nepotism have been made against [[Bruno Tobback]], the son of senator and former minister [[Louis Tobback]], a member of the Flemish socialists, became the Belgian federal government's minister for the pensions and environment at 35 in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ipe.com/magazine/tobback-making-his-mark_17630.php#.UcPF2ZzgUoI | title=Tobback: making his mark | publisher=IPE International Publishers Limited | work=Investment & Pensions Europe | date=1 March 2005 | accessdate=20 June 2013 | author=Martin Hurst}}</ref> [[Alexander De Croo]], the son of former speaker of the Belgian parliament Herman De Croo, ran for the leadership of his father's party Open VLD at age 33.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/binnenland/aid874229/alexander-de-croo-wil-voorzitter-open-vld-worden.aspx?cmt=all |title=Alexander De Croo wil voorzitter Open Vld worden |publisher=Gva.be |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> Finally there is the example of [[Maya Detiège]], the daughter of former mayor of the city of [[Antwerp]] Leona Detiège, who herself is the daughter of the former mayor of [[Antwerp]] Frans Detiège.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Among other examples are former minister Freya Vandenbossche and senator Jean Jacques De Gucht, being the daughter and son of respectively former minister Luc Vandenbossche and former minister Karel De Gucht.
=== Cambodia === Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]] and senior members of [[Parliament of Cambodia|Parliament]], are also known for their hand in getting family members into government positions. In the [[Cambodian parliamentary election, 2013|2013 Cambodian parliamentary elections]], at least eight candidates standing in the upcoming July election are sons of high-ranking [[Cambodian People’s Party]] officials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/2013050665421/National/sons-of-the-party-anointed.html |title=Sons of the party anointed |publisher= Meas Sokchea |date=6 May 2013 |accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> All ruling party sons lost, but were appointed into high government positions.
=== China === {{See also|Princelings}} For the past 3,000 years, nepotism has been common in China's clan and extended family based culture. Confucius wrote about the importance of balancing "filial piety with merit". The [[clan]]-based [[feudal society|feudal system]] collapsed during Confucius' lifetime, yet nepotism has continued through the modern age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1548234/high-level-officials-monopolise-party-promotion-mechanism-study-finds|title=High-level officials monopolise party promotion mechanism, study finds|date=6 July 2014|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Adam Bellow|title=In Praise of Nepotism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z8wSCZG9O6AC&pg=PA89|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=13 July 2004|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4000-7902-5|pages=89–92}}</ref>
=== France === In October 2009, [[Jean Sarkozy]], the second son of the President of the French Republic [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], was poised to become the director of the major {{ill|Établissement public pour l'aménagement de la région de la Défense|lt=EPAD|fr}} authority despite lacking any higher education degree and professional experience.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE59F1AH20091016 |title=Poll shows majority against job for Sarkozy's son |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 16 October 2009|accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> In 2008 he was voted regional councillor of [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]], the town of which his father had previously been mayor.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dalje.com/en-world/sarkozys-son-climbs-new-rung-on-political-ladder/156683 | title=Sarkozy´s Son Climbs New Rung On Political Ladder | publisher=Kontineo oglašavanje d.o.o. | work=dalje.com | date=16 June 2008 | accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
In September 2009, [[Rapping|rap]]-producer [[Pierre Sarkozy]], the first son of then-President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], asked {{ill|SCPP|fr|Société civile des producteurs phonographiques|vertical-align=sup}} for a financial contribution of around €10000 towards an €80000 artistic project. Because he was not a SCPP member, the request was automatically rejected. Pierre Sarkozy then went to the [[Élysée]] which led to an Élysée aide contacting the SCPP, and SCPP president [[Marc Guez]] assuring the issue would soon be favorably resolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electronlibre.info/+Nepotisme-et-Sarkozysme-acte-II,02317+ |title=Népotisme et Sarkozysme, acte II (màj) |publisher=Electronlibre.info |date= |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rue89.com/2009/11/07/apres-jean-un-coup-de-pouce-de-lelysee-pour-pierre-sarkozy-125100 |title=Après Jean, un coup de pouce de l'Elysée pour Pierre Sarkozy |publisher=Rue89.com |date=19 January 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> According to {{ill|Abeille Music|fr|Abeille Musique|vertical-align=sup}} president and SCPP member Yves Riesel, however, this would not happen as SCPP's financial help has been restricted to members only for months.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liberation.fr/politiques/0101601841-apres-jean-l-elysee-se-met-au-service-de-pierre-sarkozy |title=Après Jean, l'Elysée se met au service de Pierre Sarkozy |publisher=Liberation.fr |date= 8 November 2009|accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
=== India === {{POV section|date=October 2020}} Nepotism in India is common in politics, judiciary, business, the film industry, religious circles, arts, industry, and other types of organizations. |url=https://www.jansatta.com/national/around-50-percent-high-court-and-33-percent-supreme-court-judges-are-family-members-of-those-in-higher-echelony-of-judiciary-says-a-research-by-mumbai-based-lawyer-news-and-updates/1388885/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200527103301/https://www.jansatta.com/national/around-50-percent-high-court-and-33-percent-supreme-court-judges-are-family-members-of-those-in-higher-echelony-of-judiciary-says-a-research-by-mumbai-based-lawyer-news-and-updates/1388885/ The various judicial services exams are also infamous for these practices.<ref>{{cite news |title=Check complaints of judges' children clearing judicial exam: Sadananda Gowda asks Chief Justice |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/check-complaints-of-judges-children-clearing-judicial-exam-sadananda-gowda-to-chief-justice/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627022013/http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/check-complaints-of-judges-children-clearing-judicial-exam-sadananda-gowda-to-chief-justice/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 27, 2015 |publisher=The Indian Express |date=June 26, 2015}}</ref> [[Rahul Gandhi]], Vice-President of the [[Indian National Congress]] party, is a descendent of [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] and [[Indira Gandhi]] & [[Rajiv Gandhi]]. Data shows since 1999, the [[Indian National Congress]] has had 36 dynastic MPs elected to the Lok Sabha, with the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] not far behind with 31 dynastic MPs.<ref>https://thewire.in/politics/bjp-congress-political-dynasties-lok-sabha</ref> [[Cricket]] is also affected with nepotism, although to a lesser extent, in the form of [[Stuart Binny]], [[Rohan Gavaskar]] and very recently Arjun Tendulkar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/12/world/asia/12iht-letter12.html|title=Across India, Nepotism as a Way of Life|date=12 April 2012|work=International Herald Tribune|via=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/comment/nepotism-the-way-they-do-politics-in-india-20140327-zqnpg.html|title=Nepotism: the way they do politics in India|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 March 2014}}</ref>

=== Mauritius === Since the first democratic [[1948 Mauritian general election|elections of 1948]] and subsequent elections, the field of politics in Mauritius has been marked by a handful of families who have controlled the four major political parties which exist to this day. They are often referred to as the "modern dynasties" of Mauritian politics such as the Duval, Bérenger, Curé, Uteem, Mohamed, Boolell, Ramgoolam and Jugnauth families.For instance the Boolell family's involvement in politics started with [[Satcam Boolell]] in 1955 and he paved the way for his son [[Arvin Boolell]], nephews Satish Boolell, Anil Gayan, Sanjay Bhuckory and son-in-law Sushil Kushiram. The Duval dynasty started with ex-Lord Mayor and minister Gaetan Duval, followed by his sons Xavier and Richard as well as grand-son Adrien. Lall Jugnauth was the first of his clan to enter politics in the 1950s and he was followed by his cousins Aneerood and Ashock as well as nephew Pravind. Abdool Razack Mohamed who migrated from India in the 1930s became Lord Mayor and minister and his son Yousuf and grand-son Shakeel were also elected and served as ministers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hilbert |first1=Patrick |title=Ces dynasties qui règnent sur la politique |url=https://defimedia.info/ces-dynasties-qui-regnent-sur-la-politique |website=defimedia.info |publisher=Defimedia Group |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref>
Following the electoral defeat of the Labour Party in 2014 ex-Prime Minister [[Navin Ramgoolam]] was arrested on suspicions of money laundering and conspiracy. A police raid of his house exposed several safes containing brand new bank notes to the value of Rs 220 Million rupees, exclusive credit cards and prescription medication tablets. His girlfriend Nandanee Oogarah-Soornack, accompanied by the ex Prime Minister's daughter Xara, had escaped Mauritius to her castle in Parmes, Italy a day before the proclamation of election results with an estimated Rs 800 Million rupees. Attempts to extradite her back to Mauritius failed.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Grisham |first1=John |title=About Nandanee Soornack's case: another one bites the dust |url=https://www.lexpress.mu/idee/300261/about-nandanee-soornacks-case-another-one-bites-dust |website=lexpress.mu |publisher=L'Express |accessdate=2017-02-15}}</ref> Nandanee's humble beginnings as a divorced working class political activist and her rapid accumulation of private wealth with the help of [[Navin Ramgoolam]] was closely examined by the press and investigators. It was revealed how she collected millions of dollars through companies set up as monopolies of food outlets at the only airport in Mauritius.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nandanee Soornack Warrant for Arrest |url=https://en.indian-ocean-times.com/Mauritius-Nandanee-Soornack-the-very-close-friend-of-Navin-Ramgoolam-subject-to-an-international-arrest-warrant_a5401.html |website=Indian Ocean Times |accessdate=2015-11-20}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |last1=Soormally |first1=Raffick |title=Navin Ramgoolam : Private life, public figure, public interest |url=https://www.lexpress.mu/idee/251625/navin-ramgoolam-private-life-public-figure-public-interest |website=lexpress.mu |publisher=L'Express |accessdate=2014-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Wan |first1=James |title=Changing fortunes of Mauritius' ousted leaders |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2015/03/changing-fortunes-mauritius-ousted-leaders-150309095143234.html |website=Aljazeera.com |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=2015-03-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Soornack's press conference Much ado about nothing |url=https://defimedia.info/soornacks-press-conference-much-ado-about-nothing |website=defimedia.info |publisher=Le Defi Media |accessdate=2017-04-22}}</ref>
After the December 2014 elections the new government instigated criminal proceedings to recover about 1,000 acres (1,150 arpents) of state-owned land which had been allocated to the activists and allies of the ex-PM [[Navin Ramgoolam]] under his [[Labour Party (Mauritius)|Labour]] government since 2005. The legal documentation was lodged with the State Law Office (SLO) and Central Criminal Investigation Department (CCID) is also involved in the inquiry. The principal recipients of the various lots of Crown land were Arya Samaj activist and Labour Party activist Suryadeo Sungkur (beachfront land for his restaurant Ritum Coffee at Trou Aux Biches), Lekram Nunlall (Tarisa Resort), Navin Unoop (Voice of Hindu and Vijay Om Hamara)<ref>{{cite web |title=Terres de l'Etat: la VoH chassée de La Vigie |url=https://www.lexpress.mu/article/259309/terres-letat-voh-chassee-vigie |website=lexpress.mu |publisher=L'Express |accessdate=2015-03-01}}</ref>, Corporate Hotel Ltd (30 arpents since 2009), British American Investment (BAI) Dawood Rawat's subsidiary Tucson Ltd (20 arpents), Dhanjay Callikan (4 arpents in Balaclava for the brother of Dan Callikan, Navin Ramgoolam's former adviser and former head of Mauritius Broadcasting Corporation (MBC)), Sandranee Ramjoorawon (also known as "Sandy" the cousin of Navin Ramgoolam who received 7.3 arpents in Palmar for an apartment complex via company Dream Spa & Resorts Limited). Sandranee's husband Rajiv Beeharry, a trusted adviser of Navin Ramgoolam was also appointed as Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Mauritius Post and Cooperative Bank (MPCB). Tommy Ah-Teck received 19.7 arpents at Albion Beach for the constrution of a brand new hotel through his company Insignia Leisure Resorts Ltd. Ah-Teck's company Gamma renovated and extended the house owned by Nandanee Oogarah-Soornack, the girlfriend of ex-Prime Minister Navin Ramgoolam. Another of Ah-Teck's company (Lottotech) was granted its gambling-house permit by Navin Ramgoolam. Labour Party Treasurer Deva Virahsawmy's company Midas Acropolis was also granted 31 arpents of Crown land at St-Félix after the Labour government cancelled the development permit previously awarded to a businessmean from Reunion Island. Prior to the December 2014 elections the ministry held by Deva Virahsawmy awarded approved the Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) for land clearing of the 31 arpents in preparation of the development of a new hotel. Within the harbour precinct state land was granted to Beta Cement which is a subsidiary of Betonix which is owned by Veekram Bhunjun, who is the brother of ex-minister Rajesh Jeetah's wife. Bhunjun was also awarded 12.5 arpents at Petite-Rivière-Noire via his company Western Marina.<ref>{{cite web |title=Terres de l'Etat: ces proches du PTr ciblés par le gouvernement |url=https://www.lexpress.mu/article/259340/terres-letat-proches-ptr-cibles-gouvernement |website=lexpress.mu |publisher=L'Express |accessdate=2015-03-01}}</ref>
In 2008 when the Labour Party was in office and under [[Navin Ramgoolam]]'s rule a new private company called Pride Bridge Limited was formed by the father of [[Navin Ramgoolam]]'s girlfriend and his associates. The directors were Habeemanoo Soornack (Nandanee's father), Anishta Gooljaury (ex-wife of Rakesh Goolajaury), Surya Foolee and Lubine Holdings. The share holders of the latter company were journalist Harish Chundunsing, Doomeshwarsing Gooljaury, Kushal Lobine (Harish Chundunsing's brother-in-law) and [[Nandanee Soornack]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Enquête : quand un ancien associé de Soornack prêche la morale |url=https://defimedia.info/enquete-quand-un-ancien-associe-de-soornack-preche-la-morale |publisher=Defimedia |accessdate=2018-11-04}}</ref> Pride Bridge Ltd was soon granted 30 Arpents of ''pas géométriques'' State-owned land at Poste de Flacq in 2008 for a 'mixed development project' against a deposit of Rs 5 millions. However the owners of the well-establshed estate ''Constance La Gaité'' objected against the proposed project by questioning its legality and 6 years later Soonack's and Chundunsing's company gave up the 30 Arpents as Navin Ramgoolam was defeated at the 2014 elections, soon after which Nandanee Soornack fled to Italy.<ref>{{cite web |title=Terres de l'Etat : Chundunsing était l'associé de l'ex-copine de Navin Ramgoolam |url=https://www.inside.news/terres-de-letat-chundunsing-etait-lassocie-de-lex-copine-de-navin-ramgoolam/ |publisher=Inside News |accessdate=2019-08-30}}</ref>
Despite her defeat at the 2014 General Elections [[Maya Hanoomanjee]] became Speaker of the National Assembly as she is the niece of [[Sarojini Jugnauth]], the wife of the then Prime Minister [[Aneerood Jugnauth]] who led the MSM-PMSD government. In 2015 Maya's daughter Naila Hanoomanjee was also appointed to the newly created position of CEO of the State Property Development Company. The lease of 60 years on 2 acres of prime beachfront state-owned land in Grande Rivière Noire, in the exclusive precinct of [[Tamarin, Mauritius]] in [[Rivière Noire District|Black River]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Deux arpents de Pas Géométriques alloués à la famille Rawoo |url=https://www.5plus.mu/actualite/deux-arpents-de-pas-geometriques-alloues-la-famille-rawoo-le-depute-ismael-rawoo-garde-le |publisher=5 Plus |accessdate=2020-06-24}}</ref> The plot is near Le Morne Anglers' Club and has a panoramic view on Le Morne Brabant mountain. === Romania === [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romanian Communist]] dictator [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]]'s family members "dominated" the country for decades.<ref>{{cite book|author=Adam Bellow|title=In Praise of Nepotism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z8wSCZG9O6AC|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=13 July 2004|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4000-7902-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Edward Behr|title=Kiss the hand you cannot bite: the rise and fall of the Ceauşescus|date=21 May 1991|publisher=Villard Books|isbn=978-0-679-40128-5|page=[https://archive.org/details/kisshandyoucanno00behr/page/175 175]|url=https://archive.org/details/kisshandyoucanno00behr/page/175}}</ref> [[Elena Băsescu]], the daughter of President [[Traian Băsescu]], was elected in 2009 to the [[European Parliament]], despite the fact that she had no significant professional or political experience.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ziare.com/articole/elena+basescu+nepotism | title=Search on Elena Băsescu nepotism | work=Zaire.com | accessdate=21 June 2013 }}</ref>

The family members dispute the charges as they arise.<ref>{{cite news | title=Singapore's Lee Family and Nepotism |date=24 February 2012 |url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/society/singapores-lee-family-and-nepotism/ |newspaper=Asia Sentinel}}</ref>

Freitang, Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPrOtG3lv0QC&pg=PA208|title=Global Public Relations: Spanning Borders, Spanning Cultures|author2=Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|date=22 December 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-06129-7|page=208|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
[[Juan Antonio Samaranch Salisachs]], son of [[Juan Antonio Samaranch]], president of the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) from 1980 to 2001, has been a member of the International Olympic Committee since 2001, and his daughter, Maria Teresa Samaranch Salisachs, has been president of the Spanish Federation of Sports on Ice since 2005.<ref name="ElPais">{{Cite news | title = La larga carrera de un hombre polifacético | url = http://www.elpais.com/articulo/deportes/larga/carrera/hombre/polifacetico/elpepudep/20100421elpepudep_9/Tes | newspaper = El País | date = 21 April 2010 }}. {{in lang|es}}</ref>
=== Sri Lanka === {{See also|Rajapaksa family}} Former President of Sri Lanka, [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]], has been accused of nepotism, appointing three brothers to run important ministries and giving out other political positions to relatives, regardless of their merit. During his presidency, the Rajapaksa family held the ministries of [[Ministry of Finance and Planning (Sri Lanka)|finance]], [[defence minister|defence]], [[Ministry of Ports and Aviation (Sri Lanka)|ports and aviation]], and [[Ministry of Highways and Road Development (Sri Lanka)|highways and road development]]. The president's brother, [[Gotabhaya Rajapaksa]], was given the post of [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Defence Secretary]]. He also controlled the armed forces, the police and the Coast Guard, and was responsible for immigration and emigration. Rajapaksa appointed his brother [[Basil Rajapaksa]] as minister of [[Ministry of Youth Empowerment and Socio Economic Development (Sri Lanka)|Economic Development]]. Together, the Rajapaksa brothers controlled over 70% of Sri Lanka's public budget. Mahinda Rajapaksa's eldest brother, [[Chamal Rajapaksa]], was appointed as the [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka]], and has held many other posts before, while his eldest son, Namal Rajapaksa, is also a member of the parliament and holds undisclosed portfolios.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.economist.com/node/9299003?story_id=9299003 | work=The Economist | title=A war strange as fiction | date=7 June 2007}}</ref><ref name="atimes1">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/LK11Df02.html |title=Asia Times Online :: South Asia news, business and economy from India and Pakistan |publisher=Atimes.com |date=11 November 2010 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
Others include: his nephew, [[Shashindra Rajapaksa]], who is the former [[Chief minister of Uva]]; one of his cousins, former Sri Lankan ambassador to the [[United States]], [[Jaliya Wickramasuriya]]; and another cousin, [[Udayanga Weeratunga]], who is the former ambassador to [[Russia]]. Dozens of nephews, nieces, cousins, and in-laws have also been appointed as heads of banks, boards, and corporations.<ref name="atimes1"/>
=== United Kingdom === The [[Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury|Marquess of Salisbury]], who was [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] for three separate occasions from 1885 to 1902 for a total of approximately 14 years, appointed his nephew [[Arthur Balfour]] as [[Chief Secretary for Ireland]] in 1887 and later as Prime Minister in 1902. This is supposedly the origin of the phrase [[Bob's Your Uncle|"Bob's your uncle"]]. <ref>{{Cite book|title=Saki, a life of Hector Hugh Munro : with six short stories never before collected|last=Langguth|first= A. J.|date=1981|publisher=Simon and Schuster|others=Saki, 1870–1916.|isbn=9780671247157|location=New York|pages=65|oclc=7554446|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B4K8AAAAIAAJ}}</ref>
In February 2010, Sir Christopher Kelly, chairman of the [[Committee on Standards in Public Life]], said that more than 200 MPs used Parliamentary allowances to employ their own relatives in a variety of office roles. He suggested that the practice should be banned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8520548.stm|accessdate=27 August 2011|date=17 February 2010 | work=BBC News|title=Ban on MP spouse jobs 'essential'}}</ref>
In 2005, Councillor Ann Reid of York arranged for all nine sets of traffic lights on her daughter Hannah's wedding route through York to be switched to green for the five-car convoy. As a result, the wedding party took only 10 minutes to pass through the city.<ref>{{cite news|title=Councillor turns lights green for daughter's wedding | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1500864/Councillor-turns-lights-green-for-daughters-wedding.html | date=18 October 2005 | accessdate=9 December 2011 | newspaper=The Telegraph | location=York, UK | last=Stokes | first=Paul}}</ref>
North Yorkshire Police's Chief Constable [[Grahame Maxwell]] was disciplined by the IPCC in 2011, but refused to resign, after admitting that he assisted a relative through the first stages of a recruitment process.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Chief constable remains despite calls for resignation | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-13369301 | newspaper=BBC News | location=North Yorkshire, UK | date=12 May 2011 }}</ref>
Many Northern Irish politicians employ family members. In 2008, 19 elected politicians of the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) directly employed family members and relatives constituted 27 of its 136 staff.<ref>{{Cite news | title = DUP's two tribes | url = http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/politics/dups-two-tribes-13387086.html | newspaper = [[Belfast Telegraph]] | date = 22 February 2008 }}</ref>
[[Boris Johnson]], the current Prime Minister was accused of nepotism having appoint his brother [[Jo Johnson]] to the [[House of Lords]], having previously also appointed him to his Cabinet as [[Minister of State for Universities, Science, Research and Innovation]]. <ref>{{Cite news | title = The Queen to Confer 36 new peerages as allegations of nepotism are made | url = https://royalcentral.co.uk/features/the-queen-to-confer-36-new-peerages-as-allegations-of-nepotism-are-made-146593/ | website = [[Royal Central School|Royal Central]] | date = 31 July 2020 }}</ref>
Jesse Norman is a British [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] politician serving as [[Financial Secretary to the Treasury]] since 2019. He has personally endorsed the retrospective 2019 Loan Charge despite there being seven confirmed suicides linked to the charge, including one in which he was named. In 2020, Norman's wife, Kate Bingham was appointed chair of the UK’s Vaccine Taskforce – the group set up to lead UK efforts to find and manufacture a [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] vaccine despite other more qualified people being proposed.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kate Bingham Appointed Chair of UK Vaccine Taskforce|url=https://www.herefordvoice.co.uk/forums/topic/4128-kate-bingham-appointed-chair-of-uk-vaccine-taskforce/|access-date=2020-11-11|website=Hereford Voice|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== United States === [[Palm Beach County, Florida]] schools reinforced nepotism rules as of 2012 to ensure an "equitable work environment".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-04-12/news/fl-nepotism-palm-schools-20120412_1_nepotism-relatives-indirect-supervision|title=Palm Beach County School Board reinforces nepotism rules|work=tribunedigital-sunsentinel|access-date=12 May 2017|language=en}}</ref>
In December 2012, a report from the [[Washington Post]] indicated various nepotism practices from the [[District of Columbia]] and Northern [[Virginia]]'s [[Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority]] (MWAA), including one family with five members working for the MWAA. In 1979, [[Bill Clinton]], within weeks of being newly elected as Governor of Arkansas, appointed his wife [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] to chair of the Rural Health Advisory Committee.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Kelly (editor)|title=The First Couple: A Union of Mind and Ambition |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/01/20/us/the-inauguration-the-first-couple-a-union-of-mind-and-ambition.html |work=The New York Times |date=20 January 1993 |accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> In 1993, newly elected as President of the United States, he again [[Hillary Clinton#Health care and other policy initiatives|appointed]] his wife to chair a Task Force on National Health Care Reform. In 2013, Bill appointed his daughter [[Chelsea Clinton|Chelsea]] a member of the governing board of the [[Clinton Foundation]] and [[Clinton Foundation#Clinton Global Initiative .28CGI.29 and CGI U|Clinton Global Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McGann|first=Eileen|authorlink=Eileen McGann (author)|title=Nepotism Princess Chelsea Clinton To Write Book For Young People On Most Important Issues; No Mention Of Jobs And Student Loans Debt |url=http://thehillarydaily.com/nepotism-princess-chelsea-clinton-to-write-book-for-young-people-on-most-important-issues-no-mention-of-jobs-and-student-loans-debt/ |publisher=The Hillary Daily |date=5 May 2015 |accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Trump With Family February 1 2016.jpg|thumb|400px|The Trump family]] In 2017, President [[Donald Trump]] was accused of nepotism after appointing both his son-in-law [[Jared Kushner]] and his daughter [[Ivanka Trump|Ivanka]] (married to Kushner) into [[Senior Advisor to the President of the United States|advisory roles to the president]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Alan Yuhas |title=Trump names son-in-law Jared Kushner as senior adviser, testing anti-nepotism law |date=10 January 2017| newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/09/jared-kushner-senior-adviser-donald-trump}}</ref> Neither Jared nor Ivanka take a salary, and "advisor" is not an official tax-paid [[Civil service|government employee]] position. In 2020, President Trump appointed his son [[Eric Trump]]'s brother-in-law, Kyle Yunaska, to the position of [[NASA]] Deputy Chief of Staff. Yunaska holds a 2009 [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] and a 2007 Bachelor of Science in Management and Physics, both from [[East Carolina University]]. Yunaska is a paid government employee.{{cn|date=August 2020}}
====Legality==== Current (since 1995<ref>Haddon v. Walters, 43 F. 3d 1488 - Court of Appeals, Dist. of Columbia Circuit 1995 https://archive.today/20200217030703/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12409994638406990093</ref>) US court rulings have held that the [[White House]] itself does not constitute an "agency" for the purposes of adhering to existing anti-nepotism laws on the books.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheth|first=Sonam|title=Ivanka Trump's new White House position could be an ethical minefield |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/ivanka-trump-white-house-west-wing-donald-trump-ethics-legal-2017-3 |publisher=Business Insider |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=16 January 2020}}</ref>
=== Venezuela === Nepotism is known to be practiced by President of the Venezuela National Assembly, [[Cilia Flores]]. Nine positions in the National Assembly were filled by Flores' family members, including a mother-in-law, aunt, 3 siblings, a cousin and her mother, and 2 nephews.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/18/world/americas/18iht-venez.html?_r=0|title=Chávez family dogged by nepotism claims|date=18 February 2007|work=The New York Times|accessdate=20 June 2013|author=Simon Romero}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2008/07/08/pol_ava_cilia-flores-niega-i_08A1777279.shtml|title=Nacional y Política - eluniversal.com|date=|publisher=Buscador.eluniversal.com|language=es|accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
=== Zimbabwe === The late [[Robert Mugabe]] was reported to be preparing his wife [[Grace Mugabe]] to be the next president of Zimbabwe while he was president.<ref>{{cite news | last1=Thornycroft | first1=Peta |last2=Blair |first2=David | title=Mugabe accused of 'bedroom coup' as he prepares his wife for presidency | publisher=The Telegraph | date=31 October 2014 | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/11201716/Mugabe-accused-of-bedroom-coup-as-he-prepares-his-wife-for-presidency.html | accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> Vice President [[Joice Mujuru]] was previously considered to be the favored successor to Mugabe.<ref>JR ASAP BEATZ,ASAP PRESS</ref>
== Types of partiality == Nepotism refers to partiality to family whereas [[cronyism]] refers to partiality to an associate or [[friend]]. [[In-group favoritism|Favoritism]], the broadest of the terms, refers to partiality based upon being part of a favored group, rather than job performance.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.scu.edu/ethics/practicing/focusareas/government_ethics/introduction/cronyism.html | title=Favoritism, Cronyism, and Nepotism | publisher=Santa Clara University | accessdate=20 June 2013 | author=Judy Nadler and Miriam Schulman}}</ref>
